div.head: Account of a Tour on the Continent
Title
div.p: Although W. G. Collingwood printed this title without square brackets in Poems (1891) to indicate his intervention, the title by which this poem has become familiarly known was apparently his, as Ruskin assigned no title to the sequence as a whole in any of the extant manuscripts. What titles Ruskin supplied apply only to some individual verse and prose sections of the work. As another discrepancy, in both Poems (1891) and the Library Edition, the title is given in the table of contents as "Account of a Tour on the Continent in 1833," but the title pages of the poem itself in these editions lack the extension with the date (Poems [4o, 1891], 1:xv, 119;; Poems [8o, 1891], 1:xix, 119; Ruskin, Works, 2:xii, 340).

According to Randolph Vigne, the title "Fragments from a Metrical Journal" for the selections published in Friendship's Offering (see Composition and Publication) was invented by the editor, Thomas Pringle, although Vigne cites no source for this statement (Vigne, Thomas Pringle, 188).

div.head: Genre
div.p: Composite: verse, prose, and illustration.

div.head: Manuscripts
div.p: MS IA, MS VII, MS VIII, MS IX, MS XI.

div.head: Date
div.p: After May 1833 (possibly not earlier than October 1833) and into 1834.

div.head: Publication
div.p: Two verse selections subtitled “Andernacht” and “St. Goar” respectively, published under the main title, “Fragments from a Metrical Journal,” and signed "J. R.," in Friendshipʼs Offering; and Winterʼs Wreath . . . for 1835, 317-19; no engraving was paired with the selections, unlike another poem by "J. R." in the same volume, "Saltzburg". Another verse selection, “Ehrenbreitstein / Fragment from a Metrical Journal. / (Aetat 16.),” published in Ruskin, Poems (1850), 8-12. For the circumstances surrounding publication of "Fragments from a Metrical Journal" in Friendship's Offering by the editor, Thomas Pringle, see Ruskin, Works, 2:353-54 n. 2; and Vigne, Thomas Pringle, 188.

Selections more fully representing the "metrical journal" as originally drafted and fair-copied were edited by W. G. Collingwood in Poems (4o, 1891), 1:119-63, 281-83; Poems (8o, 1891), 1:119-63, 283-85. Collingwood drew on both Ruskin's manuscript fair copy and his draft, but limited his selections to poetry, according to the parameters of the 1891 edition. The editors of the Library Edition reprinted Collingwood's poetry texts and expanded them somewhat with additional verse taken from Ruskin's draft, but Cook and Wedderburn's most notable additions were Ruskin's prose sections for the work, revealing for the first time (in published form) the composite genre of the "Account" (Works, 2:340-87). Like Collingwood's solely verse version, Cook and Wedderburn's verse and prose version is a reconstruction from fair copy and draft. To some extent beyond the fair copy (see Ruskin, Works, 2:364 n. 1), that reconstruction is conjectural.

div.head: Fair Copy (MS IX, MS VII, MS XI)
div.p: See Discussion: Sources, for Ruskin's modeling of the "Account" on the 1830 illustrated edition of the topographical poem Italy by Samuel Rogers, with engraved vignettes after drawings by J. M. W. Turner, Thomas Stothard and Samuel Prout; and on the 1833 edition of lithographs by Samuel Prout, Facsimiles of Sketches Made in Flanders and Germany. Ruskin's manuscript fair copy of his travelogue is contained in MS IX, which is divided into sections, each entitled by a place name. In its way, Ruskin's fair copy surpasses the ambitions even of its ekphrastic models, in that he elaborating most sections, in prose as well as verse--not just one or the other--and he illustrates each section with hand-drawn imitations of the engraved vignettes and lithographs in the Rogers and Prout volumes. The text is lettered in a careful copperplate-style hand--presumably all by Ruskin, although copyists such as his mother, Margaret Ruskin, and his cousin, Mary Richardson, may have had a hand in the copying, as wel--and the vignettes are drawn in pencil and/or pen and ink on separate paper, which was then cut and pasted into place in MS IX. Ruskin copied some scenes for his vignettes directly from his sources, while for others he invented the scene but realized it stylistically in the manner of Prout or Turner or Stothard.

In the fair copy, MS IX, each section except one, "Aix la Chapelle," consists of both verse and prose; and each section, up to "St. Goar," is illustrated by at least one drawing. ("Aix la Chapelle" lacks a poem, and it is ambiguous whether this section was meant to include one; see item nos. 4-5 in the list below.) Many sections contain blank spaces likely meant to be filled with additional drawings (i.e., the cut-out slips with drawings, to be pasted into the space), which either Ruskin either never completed, or which once were positioned in the manuscript and afterward removed. Starting either with the section for "St. Goar" or with that for "Heidelberg" (the Library Edition's documentation confuses the issue, as explained below), even a single drawing is presently lacking; and the fair copy of the text ends a short way into the prose for "Heidelberg"--so at this point in MS IX, the fair-copy project clearly had broken down, and it is unlikely that once-existing drawings have been removed. These blank spaces in MS IX are as follows (measures approximated):

div.p: Folowing the recto (p. ???) containing the prose fragment for "Heidelberg," no more text appears in MS IX, although on the following 7 rectos (pp. ???) are pasted the 7 drawings described in Ruskin, Works, 2:364 n. 1--all of them showing mountain scenes. The blank versos facing each of these 7 pages would not have been adequate to contain verse and/or prose at the lengths exhibited in earlier sections; therefore, it appears that someone was using these rectos as an exhibition space for remaining drawings, without the expectation that text would ever be fair-copied, although draft text does exist in MS VIII relating to these kinds of scenes.

In either Poems (1891) or the Library Edition, the only page reproduced showing both drawing and text is that for "Ehrenbreitstein" (p. ??? in MS IX), reproduced in the Library Edition alone (Ruskin, Works, 2:356 opp.). Otherwise, the Library Edition reproduces two plates from Collingwood Poems (1891)--"Watch-tower at Andernach (1833)," in the manner of Prout, and taken apparently from a sketchbook; and "The Jungfrau from Interlachen (1833)" (Poems [4o, 1891], 1:128 opp., and 1:140 opp., respectively; Ruskin, Works, 2:354 opp., and 2:380 opp.). Both editions situate the "Andernach" plate with its corresponding poem and verse; the "Jungfrau" plate, however, is placed opposite "The Alps from Schaffhausen" in Poems (1891), and opposite "Chamouni" in the Library Edition. Surprisingly, the "Jungfrau" drawing, unlike the "Watch-tower" sketch, has the appearance of a vignette made for MS IX. If it ever was included in that manuscript, however, Collingwood must have removed it prior to the editing of the Library Edition, as Cook and Wedderburn do not record anything like it in their notes documenting placement of draings (although, as already remarked, at least one of their notes is muddled).
Some of Ruskin's drawings or draft for the "Account" have been reproduced in various places, including Hunt, Wider Sea, plate 23a.
Other hands than Ruskin's--possibly those of Margaret Ruskin or Ruskin's cousin, Mary Richardson--are responsible for fair copies of the portions of the "Account" in MS VII and MS XI. . . .

div.head: Draft (MS IA, MS VIII)
div.p: Draft, both of text that was fair-copied and of text left in rough form, survives on loose sheets in MS IA, and in MS VIII, a notebook that Ruskin had used since 1831--and would continue to use through 1836--for rough copy of poetry and other imaginative work. The draft for the "Account" in MS VIII first appears following draft for "My Father's Birthday: The Month of May", Ruskin's 10 May birthday tribute for 1833--logically so, as the family departed for the tour following John James's birthday. In this section of MS VIII, it is not in all instances clear, however, what writing Ruskin intended for the "Account," as he did not entitle the work as a whole, and left many of its parts untitled, as well (see MS VIII: Contents, Section b.

There is no indication how much time elapsed between composition of the birthday ode in MS VIII, which must have preceded 10 May 1833, and the ensuing entry of draft for the "Account"; Ruskin may not have resumed use of MS VIII until following the family's return from the Tour of 1833 in September. It is possible also that, whenever he took up this notebook to draft the "Account," he had already begun the work in another manuscript or manuscripts. For example, two loose sheets, which are now bound in MS IA, contain draft of portions of the work that are not otherwise represented in the MS VIII draft, and these versions of texts are unquestionably prior to those texts' corresponding fair copies in MS IX, since revisions made to the MS IA drafts are incorporated into the fair copies. Could these MS IA sheets have been composed during the journey itself? There appears no way of knowing for sure.

Nor does any extant manuscript evidence establish when Ruskin began fair-copying vis-à-vis drafting. One broad inference on this count does seem well enough justified, however, if not definitively provable: namely, two MS IA draft sheets, which consist solely of verse treatments of places belonging, topographically, to the earliest stages of the tour (i.e., in northern France and Belgium), preceded the MS VIII draft. The latter, in contrast, begins by describing a very late stage of the tour (e.g., Chamouni), and proceeds in no logical topographical order--in fact, turning backward in the middle of the sequence to draft prose accounts of earliest stages of the journey (e.g., for Brussels, and for the Meuse). Clearly, then, Ruskin could not have begun the MS VIII draft prior to the advanced stage of the tour with which it begins ("The Source of the Arveron">; and he could not have started the fair copy in MS IX prior to drafting its opening prose sections, which appear well along in the MS VIII draft. The logical inference, then, is that Ruskin started the draft in MS VIII after the family's return home from the tour in late September 1833; and he started the fair copy, with its elaborate drawings, even later in the fall or the winter of 1833-34. That several of the drawings for earlier sections--those for "Cassel" and "Lille," if not one for "Calais," as well--are based on lithographs in Prout's Facsimiles argues even more strongly for Ruskin starting the fair copy at home, in late 1833, as the huge Prout folio could not have been carried on the journey itself.

It may be hazarded, moreover, that the MS IA sheets containing solely verse accounts of the northern France and Belgian stages of the tour represent the earliest conception of the "Account"--whether or not the sheets themselves (or a draft on which they are based) were composed while the family was in progress on the tour. There survives also a sheet--likewise later bound into MS IA, but quite different in appearance from the other two sheets--which does contain both prose and verse, but the selections pick out points along the entire tour, beginning to end, as a kind of epitome of the whole. I hypothesize that this sheet represents a transitional stage, a generic reconsideration of the work, along the way to the composite form that emerges in MS VIII and MS IX. In other words, a still broader inference from the draft remains, and an arresting one, is that Ruskin arrived at the composite genre of his work--verse, prose, and illustration--only gradually and comparatively late in the compositional process, and that the initial plan was for a solely verse account. Another This hypothesis radically contradicts--indeed, inverts--Ruskin's narrative in Praeterita of how Rogers's and Prout's ekphrastic works brought about a kind of vocational conversion, prior to departure or even proposing the journey of 1833.

In Table 1, the columns list the sequence of poems, and/or prose, and/or drawings as they appear in the respective manuscripts or parts of manuscripts. The columns are ordered according to Ruskin's probable chronological sequence of work on the manuscripts, although this sequence is necessarily conjectural, and his work in more than one manuscript may well have overlapped (e.g., he may have begun fair-copying in MS IX while still drafting in MS VIII). Rather than placing MS IX in column 1, as necessarily representing a teleological intention, the table allows for an unfolding intentionality. The table complements the following analysis of MS IA and MS VIII.

The manuscript portions of the "Account" bound into MS IA (a compilation bound by Ruskin's editors, not by Ruskin himself) consists, first, of two sheets of identical size and containing text running continuously from one sheet to the next. The first of these sheets is partly in the hand of John James Ruskin, and partly in the hand of his son, while the second sheet is entirely in John's hand. Together, these two sheets contain versions of the first five poems of the "Account" as fair-copied in MS IX, and in the order that those poems appear in the fair copy: "Calais," "Cassel," "Lille," "Brussels," and "The Meuse." While these versions appear too neat to represent initial draft, they do contain substitutions, and these changes are reflected in the fair copy, MS IX, suggesting that the sheets may represent interim versions of these poems between a lost earlier draft of these poems and their ultimate fair copies in MS IX. Ruskin numbered the lines of the poems sequentially (1-173)--that is, without starting his numbering anew with each poem--confirming he had established their sequence (and their sequence was established by topography, of course, as the traveler followed the route from Calais to Brussels [see Tour of 1833]).

A third sheet in MS IA, which differs physically from the other two sheets, does present a prose section--a draft of the prose for "Calais," as fair-copied in MS IX. This is followed by draft of two poems that, in topographical terms, skip far ahead in the tour to "Passing the Alps" and "Milan Cathedral"; and then two more poems follow that, in topographical terms, go backwards to the Rhine, "Andernacht" and "St. Goar." The Alpine and Milan poems do not appear at all in the fair copy, MS IX (this draft is the sole source of copytext for these poems in Poems 1891 and the Library Edition versions of the "Account"). The Rhine poems do appear in MS IX fair copies, versions that incorporate substitutions shown in this draft. (These are not the versions of those two Rhine poems as they would be published in Friendship's Offering for 1835.) Since the corresponding prose sections for "Andernacht" and "St. Goar" are drafted near the beginning of the "Account" draft in MS VIII, it is reasonable to conclude that this sheet represents a stage of composition between the other two MS IA sheets containing the first five poems, and the rather chaotic draft (in terms of topographical sequence) taken up in the draft notebook, MS VIII. It may be also be hazarded, if more cautiously, that this third sheet represents a transition in terms of work's generic character--from a verse travelogue to a composite work. Possibly carrying along with that development, MS VIII contains rough pen-and-ink sketches.

An additional clue tending to confirm this proposed sequence of composition is Ruskin's line numbering for verse draft, which appears both in the MS IA sheets and in the portion of MS VIII devoted to drafting the "Account." As mentioned, the five poems in the two MS IA sheets in John's and John's James's hands are numbered continuously 1 to 173. In the third MS IA sheet, starting with "Passing the Alps," the line numbering is again continuous from poem to poem, 360-429. The line numbering in MS VIII begins with line 506. The line numbering carries relentlessly forward along with the physical sequence of the drafts of poems, without regard for their topographical logic (which is mixed), but this fact would seem to reinforce the connection of the numbering with the sequence of composition. (That is, the numbering bears no relation to the ultimate rearrangement of these sections for the fair copy.)One cannot assume, it is true, that the sequence of draft in MS VIII represents exactly the sequence of composition. Take, as an example of possible inconsistency with appearances, the prose section on Brussels, which begins on 62r, three-quarters down the page. Ruskin entitled this segment "Part of Brussels," and extended the draft halfway through 62v. Here, the draft stops in mid-sentence (". . . circumnavigating," for traversing), and is followed by a poem, "Oh softly blew the mounting breeze" (entitled "Chiavenna" in the 1891 Poems and the Library Edition). Ruskin numbered these lines 810-22, which is continuous with a previous installment of verse (778-809, for a quite different poem, "The Black Forest," as so-called in the later editions). The remainder of the prose passage on Brussels ("perambulating . . . tread on it softly") begins at the top of the next recto, 63r, and finishes on 63v. One inference is that Ruskin wrapped the prose around the poem, already drafted in its place, on 62v. Another explanation, however, is that the sequence of composition was what it appears to be, but the abrupt shifts between prose and poetry provide a clue about the process of fair-copying. In the fair copy of this prose passage on Brussels in MS IX, a line of text ends with "circumnavigating for" (the "for" jammed against the justified right margin). The next line of text takes up with "perambulating.—Oh woe to the weather" etc. One might infer, then, that Ruskin fair-copied in MS IX as far as he had drafted in MS VIII (62v); crossed out the last word in draft (traversing), which he could not fit on the line in MS IX (hence, the run-together "circumnavigating,for"); stopped fair-copying to draft the poem "Oh softly blew the mounting breeze," numbering its lines in correct sequence; and then resumed drafting the prose passage, but changing his mind about the next word (making it "perambulating," rather than "traversing"). Either scenario can be supported by the evidence.

After the draft in MS VIII supplies the prose sections corresponding to the MS IA "Andernacht" and "St. Goar," it goes on to mix poetry about the Alpine and Italian segments of the tour with draft of prose corresponding to earlier IA poems, such prose descriptions of "Brussels" and "The Meuse." The appearance of such prose pieces may signal Ruskin's simultaneously working on the opening sections of MS IX, but that work may have been delayed until later.

In MS VIII, Ruskin's line numbering may lead to some ambiguities in what belongs to the "Account" project. Following the May 1833 birthday ode for Ruskin's father, the first piece to appear sequentially, and the first in MS VIII to exhibit line numbering, is "Oh are there spirits, can there be", which picks up the numbering system with line 506. As already suggested, many months may have elapsed between composition of the May birthday ode and this poem--a period when Ruskin was drafting the "Account" on loose sheets like those in MS IA. The ambiguity here is that this poem, "Oh are there spirits, can there be," cannot be definitely associated with the "Account" (Ruskin did not fair-copy the lyric in MS IX, but he left that version far from complete). project. The poem is separated from the preceding verse for the birthday ode by a horizontal line--a designation that, throughout MS VIII, appears to divide one work from another--but Ruskin supplies no title for this piece in particular or for the "Account" in general that establishes the start of the project's draft in MS VIII. The line numbering provides the only clue. If the lyric does belong to the "Account," its reference to spiritual presences, rather than to visible topography, would seem to have significant implications for how Ruskin thought about his first journey abroad, particularly mountain scenery.

Following this lyric, both the content of the drafts and other physical indications in the manuscript (see MS VIII: Description) leave little doubt that, in this portion of the notebook, Ruskin was exclusively occupied with the "Account." Only toward the end of this portion, draft of sections for the "Account" become mixed with drafts of the May 1834 birthday poems for John James, "The Crystal Hunter" and "The Address". While this occurrence calls into question whether the line numbering system--which persists into the birthday odes--can serve as a reliable identifier of earlier "Account" draft (such as the enigmatic "Oh are there spirits, can there be"), the run-up of the "Account" draft against the birthday poems does at least provide evidence of dating. Ruskin was now drafting the "Account" in MS VIII, and may have been simultaneously fair-copying in MS IX, into the first quarter of 1834. Moreover, judging by the scarcity of other (extant) work from winter 1833-34, compared to the outpouring of 1831-33, he was occupied with the "Account" almost exclusively. It may be that Ruskin largely completed the fair copy of the Account in MS IX through its Rhine journey sections during the winter of 1833 and early 1834, since, following the incompletely fair-copied prose section on Heidelberg, which is the last section to be attempted in MS IX, there occur only the drawings of mountain scenery, some of which may have been inspired by illustrations in Brockedon, Illustrations of the Passes of the Alps, which Ruskin received for his birthday on 22 February 1834. As he wrote his father, Brockedon's engravings carried him "again over the summits of the higher Alps, over the winding paths of Splugen, and the glaciered crest of the Simplon, and the summmer snows of the St Bernard, and the lovely plains of gentle Italy” (Burd, ed., Ruskin Family Letters, 278).

No known manuscript represents the revision of "Andernacht" and "St. Goar" for publication in Friendshipʼs Offering, which would have had to be ready by 1 August 1834, the editor's deadline to deliver the edited volume to the printer (the editor, Thomas Pringle (1789–1834), died in December of this year; Vigne, Thomas Pringle, 244, 247).

div.head: Sources
div.p: For the itinerary and other details concerning the family's journey, see Tour of 1833. The most familiar description of the literary and artistic context that surrounded both the actual journey and Ruskin's composition of the "Account" is Ruskin's story in the autobiography, Praeterita, in which he declares that "the main tenor of my life" was established in 1832 by the gift of the 1830 illustrated edition of the topographical poem Italy by Samuel Rogers, with engraved vignettes primarily by J. M. W. Turner and Thomas Stothard (and with two contributions by Samuel Prout).Prout played third fiddle, scarcely credited for his few contributions to the illustrated Italy; see Herrmann, Turner Prints, 183. While there is some uncertainty regarding the actual date of this acquisition vis-à-vis the composition of the "Account,"In the autobiography, Ruskin admits that he has "told this story so often" about the journey's poetic and artistic inspirations "that I begin to doubt its time." In Praeterita's typically dramatizing fashion, he declares that "the main tenor of my life" was set on 8 February 1832 by the birthday gift--from his father's business partner, Henry Telford--of the 1830 illustrated edition of Rogers's Italy. "It is curiously tiresome that Mr. Telford did not himself write my name in the book, and my father, who writes in it, 'The gift of Henry Telford, Esq.,' still more curiously, for him, puts no date: if it was a year later [i.e., 8 February 1833], no matter" (Ruskin, Works, 39:79). In its non-illustrated edition, Rogers's poem had been in the Ruskin household since 1828 at the latest (Burd, ed., Ruskin Family Letters, 188 n. 4)--the year that Rogers published the second part of the poem, but also the year that, in disgust over the work's tepid reception, the poet bought out remaining copies of both parts and destroyed them (see Samuel Rogers (1763-1855)). Thus, even before the poem achieved popularity in the illustrated edition, the Ruskins could count themselves among the select number of appreciative readers of Rogers's Italy, and it is possible that John or John James projected a work on this model even prior to his receiving the gift of the illustrated version. There is even an outside possibility that Ruskin did not study the illustrated edition until after the family had returned from the Continent, as John James's accounts record purchase of a copy of Italy in October 1833, just shortly after the September homecoming (Burd, ed., Ruskin Family Letters, 286 n. 1). This could well have been an additional copy, but one cannot discount the possibility that Rogers's tutelage of the Ruskins' viewing of the Alps and Italy was, during the tour itself, solely poetic, without the ekphrastic support of Turner and Stothard. the autobiography's story can be linked reliably to the family's acquisition of Samuel Prout's Facsimiles of Sketches Made in Flanders and Germany. This work, which appeared in Spring 1833 with John James Ruskin listed among the subscribers, and which is listed in the senior Ruskin's accounts for that year, is most directly credited in Praeterita for prompting the family's first major tour of the Continent: "there is no doubt . . . that early in the spring of 1833 Prout published his Sketches in Flanders and Germany. I well remember going with my father into the shop where subscribers entered their names, and being referred to the specimen print, the turreted window over Moselle, at Coblentz. We got the book home to Herne Hill before the time of our usual annual tour." More apocryphal may be the spontaneity of the outcome that Ruskin says to have arisen from enjoyment of Prout's lithographs: "as my mother watched my father's pleasure and mine in looking at the wonderful places, she said, why should we not go and see some of them in reality? My father hesitated a little, then with glittering eyes said--why not? And there were two or three weeks of entirely rapturous and amazed preparation" (Ruskin, Works, 39:79; Burd, ed., Ruskin Family Letters, 286 n. 1).

Regardless of how the family's planning actually unfolded respecting the acquisition of these two books, implicit in the story is the books' representative role (whether exclusively so or not) in the family's conceptualization of their northern and southern destinations. Prout's Facsimiles provided a pictorial tour through Belgium and Germany, whereas Rogers led the reader on the more traditional Grand Tour of the South. The books contrasted also in their material representations. The Facsimiles consisted of 50 lithographic prints of picturesque architectural sites in Belgium and Germany, with no letterpress--only the place names lettered directly onto the lithographic stone, as part of images, identifying the locales depicted. The lithographs, then a new medium in Britain, would have struck the Ruskins with their dramatically large size (22 by 15 inches) and watercolor-like texture, as compared with the exquisite preciousness of Rogers's Italy, illustrated with vignette engravings (2-3 inches by 3-4 inches). The Italy was also ekphrastic in the late-eighteenth-century manner, with Rogers's topographical poem assuming priority in topographical description, despite the poem's having gained its popularity solely byt means of the graphic enhancements.

Despite these material and substantive contrasts in framing the Ruskins' tour, both books represented the bourgeoning publishing trade that responded to the growth in British travel on the Continent in the decades immediately after Waterloo; and both complemented improvements in transport and tourism with their show of technical advances in printing--lithography in Prout's case, steel engraving in Rogers's (for further information about these volumes, see Samuel Prout (1783-1852) and Samuel Rogers (1763-1855); and for the improvements in tourism and transport, brought about primarily by the rapid development of steam-packet crossings from Britain to norther France and the Low Countries, see Tour of 1825 and Tour of 1833).

While Ruskin's later autobiographical account doubtless lays too much weight on these two particular publications, Rogers's and Prout's books can be usefully understaood as representative of changing modes of travel and travel art and literature in the 1820s and 1830s. Critics and biographers, following Ruskin's cue in limiting their view to just these two books, have been lead to treat Ruskin's own literary and artistic response, his "Account," as merely derivative--an imitation--of these sources. For that matter, the "Account" is even more falsely treated as an imitation solely of the 1830 illustrated Italy, with Prout's influence passed over. But the "Account" not only responds creatively, and not just derivatively, to these two books, but also reflects with considerable complexity the context of the decades after Waterloo that made these books possible and successful.

As remarked in Composition and Publication, the compositional history of the "Account" suggests competing or evolving generic intentions, from the poetic travelogue in early MS IA draft to the composite work developed in MS VIII and MS IX. These evolving manuscript states may point to creative tensions that Ruskin discovered in his sources and creatively exploited. The two MS IA sheets in John's and John James's hands, being solely in verse form, reflect the influence of Rogers's poetic travelogue (although Italy does contain some prose); yet, Ruskin's (and his father's?) poems adapt the poetic travelogue, which Rogers organizes around the traditional Grand Tour, to the Nord-Pas-de-Calais and Belgium, the northern sites depicted by Prout. The MS VIII draft and MS IX fair copy, in contrast, use both verse and prose to represent the northern as well as southern segments of the tour. Thus, the MS IA sheets represent a stage when the project aspired to an exclusively "metrical journal"--the term used ultimately and inaccurately to describe the project when excerpts were published in 1835 as "fragments of a metrical journal"--and reflect the influence of Rogers and the tradition of the eighteenth-century topographical poem. The later compositional stage, incorporating prose and illustration, reaches beyond Rogers's neoclassicism to attempt a mixed genre symptomatic of a transitional stage in English travel writing and artistic representation that emerged in the 1820s and 1830s.

In these decades, this emergent touristic experience was most vivid in routes through northern Europe rather than along the well-worn path of the Grand Tour to Italy. Ruskin's memory in Praeterita of the significance of Prout's Facsimiles in prompting the family's journey is corroborated by the novelty that the artist's representations of towns in northern France, Belgium, and Germany afforded to British viewers in 1833. While such scenic representations grew more familiar in the later 1830s and 1840s from similar projects by T. M. Richardson (1784-1848), J. D. Harding (1797-1863), T. S. Boys (1803-74), Clarkson Stanfield (1793-1867), and Louis Haghe (1806-85), Prout was a foundational influence on artists seeking architectural picturesque subjects in this region (Lockett, Samuel Prout, 76).

Prout's role in this transition remains an emphasis even in Ruskin's later writing about the artist. Despite Ruskin's changing purposes over the years, his writing always refers back to Prout's discovery of northern Europe as the artist's distinction in these earlier decades. For example, in his 1849 article on Prout for the Art Journal, Ruskin characterizes Prout's first tour of the region in terms of conversion and destiny, "the painter's vocation . . . fixed from that hour. The first effect upon his mind was irrepressible enthusiasm, with a strong feeling of a new-born attachment to Art, in a new world [in northern Europe] of exceeding interest." While the essay is in keeping with the concerns of The Seven Lamps of Architecture and The Stones of Venice--situating Prout's personal discovery of vocation within a larger history framed by a critique of misguided modernist feeling (Prout "became the interpreter of a great period of the world's history, of that in which age and neglect had cast the interest of ruin over the noblest ecclesiastical structures of Europe, and in which there had been born at their feet a generation . . . which understood not their meaning" and which would destroy those structures, in Ruskin's view, by way of "resoration" [Ruskin, Works, 12:311, 314])--the core of the argument is built arount Prout's discovery of Flanders. Likewise, in his 1879-80 Notes on Prout prepared to accompany his loan of drawings for exhibition at the Fine Art Society, Ruskin's experience of Prout in the 1830s is preserved in his later purpose, which is to hearken autobiographically to his youth spent with his father in regular attendance at the Old Water Colour Society. There, Ruskin alleges, Prout's discovery of northern Europe earned the artist "by common and tacit consent" the "privilege . . . to introduce foreign elements of romance and amazement into this--perhaps slightly fenny--atmosphere of English common sense" typical of the homelier subjects of other artists (Ruskin, Works, 14:390). This latter characterization comes closest to Praeterita's presentation of the role of Prout's Facsimiles as prompting the family's "amazed" sudden departure for this romantic travel starting in northern France and Belgium (Ruskin, Works, 39:79).

In 1833, travel in the Pas-de-Calais and Flanders remained comparatively unfamiliar to English tourists except as a route to be got over as quickly as possible on the way to France and Germany. (Prout's even more far-flung destinations in Eastern Europe, such as Prague, which he depicted in the Facsimiles and exhibited watercolors, found little success with the public.) Since the early 1820s, Prout had established his lead in depicting the market towns of this region for the Old Water Color Society. Accordingly, his Facsimiles of 1833 may well have served as a kind of guide for the Ruskins to adopt a more leisurely and attentive pace through these towns. In fact, the Ruskins traced a route through northern France and Germany similar to that of the artist's sketching tour of 1821, although the sequence of the published lithographs in Facsimiles departs somewhat from that route, opening with a market scene occupying the square in front of the Hotel de Ville, Brussels (see Lockett, Samuel Prout, 50, 59; and compare Samuel Prout (1783-1852) and Tour of 1833).

Neither Prout in the 1820s nor the Ruskins in the early 1830s could find their way in the region with the assistance of what became the vade mecum for English travelers landing in Normandy and the Low Countries--Murray's Hand-book for Travellers on the Continent, as this guidebook was not published until 1836. Murray's Hand-book is now often credited with initiating the modern genre of the English traveler's guidebook, but earlier journeys like the Ruskins', taken between the reopening of the Continent after Waterloo and the late 1830s, had to rely on a transitional period of travel writing and illustration, of which Prout's Facsimiles formed a part. As Pieter François has shown, prior to the publication of Murray's Hand-book, there appeared between 1815 and the 1830s numerous examples of the guidebook genre in an emerging and somewhat inchoate form, particularly as related to the Low Countries. After Waterloo, the modern guidebook gradually emerged as a genre distinct from the travel "account" in offering mainly practical travel advice, as compared with the traditional travel account's emphasis on topographical description and narrative from an individual (but not too individualistic) perspective. In the transitional, post-Waterloo period, however, genres became mixed: the emerging, modern guidebooks, along with their practical advice, often retained traces of the eighteenth-century travel account--for example, by presenting recommendations in epistolary form--whereas, correspondingly, the more traditional travel accounts of the period (which became legion when the Continent reopened) recommended themselves in a crowded field by proferring the detailed practical advice more typical of the guidebook (François, “If Itʼs 1815, This Must Be Belgium”, 76-82).

In 1833-34, this transitional and eclectic period of travel writing is reflected in the Ruskins' book purchases, both before setting out on their journey and following their return. Prior to departure, besides admiring Rogers's Italy and Prout's Sketches, the family armed themselves with practical resources--a German grammar, and a work by Mariana Starke (1762-1838), whose travel books are characterized by both François and James Buzard as characteristic of the transitional period of travel writing, displaying characteristics both of the guidebook and the travel account, and whose work Charles Batten similarly describes as moving away from the decorum of the eighteenth-century travel account that balances information with entertainment (François, “If Itʼs 1815, This Must Be Belgium”, 76, 90; Buzard, Beaten Track, 68-70; Batten, Pleasurable Instruction, 30). The Starke work may have been Travels in Europe, a popular guidebook first published by Murray in 1820 as Travels on the Continent, and available in a "considerably enlarged" eighth edition in 1833.Starke's Travels in Europe along with her more portable Information and Directions for Travellers on the Continent, which was published on the Continent by Galignani, approached closely, Buzard remarks, to the form of the modern guidebook. Even Starke's much earlier success, Travels in Italy (1800), had been "felt by many before the rise of the Murray and Baedeker guides to be the best available vade-mecum for Italy," yet that "work was by no means single-mindedly devoted to the role of 'handbook.'" Characteristic of this transitional period of travel writing, Travels in Italy "has the appearance, when we look back at it with generic presuppositions founded on Murray and Baedeker, of an impressionistic 'travel book'"--that is, as still relying, despite its "serving as a makeshift [modern] 'handbook' in the absence of any alternative," on such eighteenth-century conventions as a series of letters containing the traveler's personal impressions balanced by judicious reflection (Buzard, Beaten Track, 68, and see 69-70). Compendious as it was, however, Travels in Europe offered no route from Calais to Cologne, which the Ruskins followed in order to access the Rhine; for while Starke's updated guide did supply information on Germany and many other regions of Europe in an appendix, the main text remained traditionally focused on getting the traveler first to Paris, and then to Italy. Yet, once arrived in the South, the Ruskins would have found Starke's work handy for its more modern, guidebook-like feature of convenient "catalogues of the most valuable specimens of Architecture, Painting, and Sculpture, in France, Italy, Magna Graecia, Sicily, and Germany; with the opinions of Nardini, Venuti, Winckelmann, and Visconti, on some of the most celebrated Works of Art" (Starke, Travels in Europe, 2).

Following the family's return in autumn 1833, and during Ruskin's ongoing composition of the "Account" in 1834, John James continued to acquire travel publications typical of this eclectic, transitional period. There were travel accounts written in the immediate post-Waterloo period by Vicomte François René de Chateaubriand (1768-1848) and by William Stewart Rose (1775-1843), an associate of Byron and Rogers.John James's account book does not identify the titles, but Van Akin Burd suggests Chateaubriand's Souvenirs d'Italie, d'Angleterre, et d'Amérique (1815) and Rose's Letters from the North of Italy (1819). There was also a "P. Rhine" (perhaps Pilgrims of the Rhine, a decidedly eclectic work by Edward Bulwer-Lytton, published in this year), alongside a work by Horace-Bénédict de Saussure (1740-99), whose writings combined travel narrative with scientific observation of the Alps (for John James Ruskin's 1833-34 booklists, see Burd, ed., Ruskin Family Letters, 286 n. 1).

By comparison with these changes, and with the bustle of multiple, inventive genres of travel writing that were vying to serve the rising tide of middle-class tourism on the Continent. Rogers's neoclassical poetry seems out of step. Turner complied with Rogers's style, reining in his apocalyptic manner in favor of nondramatic perspective and essentializing representations of landscape and buildings (see Holcomb, "Neglected Classical Phase of Turner's Art"). Yet, the 1830 illustrated version of Rogers's Italy likewise drew on up-to-date printing methods, exploiting the popularity of the literary "annuals," illustrated by steel engravings that allowed durable mass production for mass production and wide distribution. Even within this mode of production, the 1830 Italy was innovative, in combining intaglio illustration with relief type on the same page (see Samuel Rogers (1763-1855)). Influential and popular as this best-seller was, however, its significance lies in its representative status. It is no accident that Ruskin received the illustrated Italy as a birthday present in the same period when his cousin, Charles Thomas Richardson (1811–34), presented him with a copy of the steel-engraved annual, Friendshipʼs Offering, published by Charles's employer, Smith, Elder & Co., as the latest and most sumptuous addition to the crowding field. The editor of that 1829 or 1830 volume was Thomas Pringle (1789–1834), the poet and editor who would take Ruskin himself under his wing and introduce the prodigy to the public as "J. R.," author of the “Fragments from a Metrical Journal” in Friendshipʼs Offering; and Winterʼs Wreath . . . for 1835.

At the same time, Ruskin stepped backward in time into the Regency world of the "man of taste," Samuel Rogers (1763-1855), when Pringle ushered the prodigy to St. James Place, Rogers's palace of neoclassical art, to meet the great man. The only known records of this episode, Ruskin's stories about the meeting in much later autobiographical writing, again retain a germ of an essential experience of the 1830s--namely, that the boy "knew more of the vignettes [in Italy] than the verses" (Ruskin, Works, 34:96, and see also 35:93). Of course he did, as he had been so obsessively studying and copying the engravings for his own "Account," even imitating the fine, intaglio lines in his drawings. The boy probably knew better than Rogers did how this modern refinement of intaglio technique compared with the radically different feel of the new lithography, since Ruskin had imitated both results for his "Account." In fact, while the circumstances are not documented, it is a reasonable guess that Pringle gained Ruskin's access to Rogers by borrowing MS IX beforehand, to exhibit their precocious imitations of the illustrated Italy to the boy's fellow entrepreneur of modern, refined ekphrastic writing.

Let's say that the audience with Rogers took place in early 1834, when Ruskin had pushed on with his fair copy of the "Account" in MS IX. By that time, it must have been decided that he would contribute selections from the "Account" to Friendshipʼs Offering; and Winterʼs Wreath . . . for 1835. The entitling of these sections in the annual as "fragments" from a "metrical journal," and printing them without their prose or pictorial accompaniments, return the project full-circle to its apparently purely verse beginnings in MS IA; and in so doing, bring the project round to knowing more of the verses than the vignettes, after all. This courteous nod to the eighteenth century would have been arranged not only by Pringle but also, presumably, by his friend, John James Ruskin, whose hand is manifest in the earliest, fully poetic MS IA stage of the project. In this instance, a struggle of intentions between an eighteeenth-century verse genre and a nineteenth-century composite genre won out in the fathers' favor. In the same volume of Friendship's Offering, however, Ruskin also contributed the poem, "Saltzburg," written to order as accompaniment to a steel-engraved plate, meant to entertain the modern middle-class consumer.

div.head: National Identities
div.p: Signs of havoc caused by the July Revolution in France and the Belgian Revolution of 1830 were still being marked six years later by Murray's Hand-book for Travellers on the Continent; and decades later, Ruskin would contrast Prout's quietude of manner with the state of medieval French architecture "such as her vestiges remained after all the wreck of revolution and recoil of war had passed over them" (Ruskin, Works, 14:395). In the boyhood "Account," however, Ruskin appears completely unconscious of recent political history. Inevitably, as an English travel narrative, the "Account" does comment on national identities, seeing Calais as "an introduction to France, and to the French," but the narrator moralizes in non-specific terms. On the road between Calais and Brussels, climbing to the top of Mont Cassel, the narrator points out the "fifteen battle-fields" visible from the eminence that tell "a fearful tale of the ready ire of nations, yet looking as green and peaceful as if they had never been watered with blood." Nothing is said about such signs of recent conflict as the destruction of the ancient Abbey of St. Bertin at St. Omer; rather, while the narrator, passing St. Omer, sneers at the "serpent folds" of "Romes religion" hidden beneath a religious procession, the English anti-Catholic sentiment associated with that place was as old as the Gunpowder Plot--the Jesuit College at St. Omer having been implicated in that history.

Similarly out of date is the poem's passage through France to Belgium and the neglect of any commentary on the Belgian character. The Belgian Revolution of 1830 had established the Kingdom of Belgium as a state separate from the United Kingdom of the Netherlands. English attitudes to the new kingdom--as Pieter François finds, examining such popular sources as travel guidebooks--were initially divided along party lines, with Whigs approving the Catholic revolutionaries and Tories supporting the Protestant Dutch kingdom (Murray's 1836 Hand-book remained staunchly Tory). Over the course of the 1830s, however, British opinion unified around a myth of Belgium as a "little Britain" that had copied its neighbor's constitutionalism and rising industrialization, shared a royal connection in King Leopold I, and even harbored an alleged "hidden" protestantism beneath the nation's apparent Catholic national identity (François, "Belgium", 663-64). Yet Ruskin's impressions of Belgium in the "Account" neither reflects the partisan views of Murray's Hand-book, which condemns the Belgians for lacking the "heroic patriotism" and "high-minded courage and ceaseless perseverence" of their Protestant Dutch neighbors and for possessing "a coarseness of manners" and "debasement of the national character" (Hand-book for Travellers on the Continent, 78); nor do his views share in the myth of the Englishness of the Belgian character. Brussels is. . . JJR as subscriber among aristocrats in 1833, Prout's publications, apart from his few contributions to engravings in the Rogers volume, could supply no direction to the Ruskins' southern journey, as the complementary volume to the Facsimiles, the Sketches Made in France, Switzerland, and Italy, was not published until 1839).

div.p: , . This hypothesis--that Ruskin had been steadily fair-copying and drawing in MS IX, until his attention was captured by imitating Brockendon in late February 1834--appears corroborated by comparing the sequence of sections in the fair copy against the progress of draft in MS VIII. To facilitate the following comparisons of fair copy with rough draft, Table 1 arranges the sections of the Account in columns according to manuscript. Column ?, listing MS IX, the illustrated fair copy, should be read as the base column, for only here are the sections listed in the order they appear in manuscript. Other manuscript copies of sections (in IA, VII, VIII, and XI) are matched against the base column in order to establish the relationship between drafting and fair-copying. Thus, the columns for MSS IA, VII, VIII, and XI do not show the sequential order of sections in those manuscripts, but the sequences can be inferred from column ?, which lists Ruskin’s continuous line numbering. Ruskin’s line numbering, which he used in MSS IA and VIII, is carried sequentially throughout the poems; i.e., he did not start his numbering anew with each poem but numbered continuously from poem to poem, skipping over the prose draft. Presumably the system served Ruskin as a guide to fair-copying. In the fair copy, MS IX, he left some pages blank for prose or poetry to be added later but pasted in illustrations, and he filled other pages with writing but left blank spaces for illustrations. To work in this piecemeal manner, he must have known the length of the sections to be copied--hence, his line numbering. It is tempting to declare that the numbering also establishes the sequence of composition; however, the numbering could have been added at any time after the poems’ drafting. ; however, the order of sections in these manuscripts is more conveniently listed in Part 1. For other directions to interpreting Table 1, see the notes at the bottom of the table.) The chronology of composition is equally conjectural, since Ruskin left no dates on draft or fair copy. The first five poems of the travelogue (“Calais,” “Cassel,” “Lille,” “Brussels,” and “The Meuse”), without their respective prose sections, appear on two sheets in MS IA in the order they are fair-copied in the illustrated version, MS IX (see part 1, MS IA, “Content,” g). These sheets are mostly in Ruskin’s hand but partly in John James’s. What stage of draft they represent cannot be determined, except that they probably predate the fair-copy MS IX, since they share a characteristic of the MS VIII draft--namely, Ruskin’s line numbering, The line numbering on the two MS IA sheets containing the first five poems begins at one and carries through 173 for the first four poems; the fifth poem, “The Meuse,” is unnumbered, because it is crowded sideways on the second sheet, with no space left for numbering. One might infer from these two sheets in MS IA containing the initial poems of the Account that Ruskin composed substantial portions of the verse prior to the prose. Such a conclusion cannot be warranted, however, in absence of the purpose of these sheets. The pieces fair-copied in MS VII cannot be dated, except as probably postdating the last use of that notebook for the fair copy of “Athens.” Since the draft of that epic was abandoned in 1832, prior to the Account project, this lower limiting date is of no use. Only the MS VIII pieces are unquestionably rough drafts and probably more or less sequential, therefore providing clues to the order of composition, if not precise dates. Also, on the back endpapers of MS VIII, Ruskin entered a list of proposed sections of the poem (reproduced in WS, pl. 6b). Table 1 shows that the first draft sections in MS VIII to be fair-copied in MS IX were the prose sections on Andernacht and St. Goar. At this stage MS IX falters to a halt, with spaces for drawings left blank, and the fair copy following St. Goar--on Heidelberg--left incomplete. Since the fter St. Goar, the Meuse, Cologne, and Brussels--respectively, the fourth, fifth, eleventh, twelfth, fifteenth and seventeenth Account-related entries in MS VIII. This may suggest, though with no certainty, that by the time Ruskin was about halfway into the MS VIII draft (i.e., the fifteenth and seventeenth of thirty-seven items in MS VIII), he had already begun fair-copying and illustrating MS IX, i.e., the poetry and prose sections of “Calais,” “Cassel,” “Lille,” “Brussels,” “Meuse,” “Aix-la-Chapelle,” “Cologne,” “Andernacht,” “Ehrenbreitstein,” “St. Goar,” and “Heidelberg.” (Note that MS IX’s relatively late prose sections for “Andernacht” and “St. Goar” occur quite early in MS VIII, the fourth and fifth entries, while “Aix-la-Chapelle” and “Ehrenbreitstein” and “Heidelberg” occur later among the MS VIII entries, scattered between the twenty-first and thirty-third.) Since the verse portions of the five opening sections of MS IX exist in MS IA copy, one might hazard that Ruskin began by drafting, fair-copying, and illustrating the Account as a response to Samuel Prout’s Sketches in Flanders and Germany. MS VIII, despite its drafts related to the German stages of the journey, appears more closely modeled on Samuel Rogers’s Italy. Putting aside the prose sections on Andernacht and St. Goar, MS VIII begins with a cluster of mountain pieces--the Arveron and Arve pieces, the sighting of the Alps from Schaffhausen, the crossing of the Alps into Italy--and then roughly alternates Italian and Swiss with German descriptions. In the absence of benchmark dates except at the point when Ruskin paused amid the “Tour” in MS VIII to compose his father’s birthday poems for 1834 (see app. A, MS VIII, “Content,” [b]), various scenarios are possible. Unquestionably, the fair-copying in MS IX was begun at home, following the journey, since sections as early as “Lille” comment on Italian stages of the itenerary (although the tipped-in drawings conceivably could have been started during the journey). This fair-copying may have started from draft, now lost though possibly represented by sheets in MS IA, that could have been composed during the journey itself, or soon following it. If so, the draft in MS VIII shows Ruskin composing for the on-going fair-copying of Lowland and German sections and, simultaneously, for the later largely Swiss and Italian sections that were never fair-copied. (Ruskin did, however, place illustrations, with no text, in MS IX that depict mountain and lake scenes for the later sections; see Works 2:364 n. 1. For these sketches, he also put to use an older rough-draft notebook, MS VI; see app. A, “Content” [e].) The illustration of the Swiss passages could have been spurred, not only by Rogers’s Italy, but also by William Brockendon’s Illustrations of the Passes of the Alps and H. B. Saussure’s Voyages dans les Alpes, both of which Ruskin received for his birthday in February 1834 (RFL 278). Alternatively, MS VIII could represent Ruskin’s initial poetic response to the Continent--the sublimities of the Alps and the Italian lakes, mediated by Scott, Rogers, and Byron, taking precedence over the Proutian picturesque. (Even the early occurring “Andernacht” and “St. Goar” prose sections concern the psychology of mountain and hill viewing.)
